item.title: Covid infections rise by two-thirds in UK - ONS
item.description: Increasing numbers of infections are likely to be caused by the so-called Indian, or Delta, variant.

item.title: Facebook suspends Trump accounts for two years
item.description: Former US President Donald Trump called the platform's decree "abuse" and "an insult" to his voters.

item.title: Covid-19: Airlines add capacity ahead of Portugal change
item.description: The country will be removed from the UK's travel green list on Tuesday, prompting a race for return flights.

item.title: Rich nations 'millimetre away' from tech tax deal
item.description: Finance chiefs from the G7 are meeting in London, and the French finance minister said a minimum tax deal is very close

item.title: Covid in Scotland: Restriction levels ease for millions of Scots
item.description: Many areas of the country go from level two to level one but there are no changes for much of the central belt.

item.title: Denmark parliament approves giant artificial island off Copenhagen
item.description: Lynetteholm aims to house 35,000 people and protect the port, but environmentalists have concerns.

item.title: Nepalese PM calls on UK to provide vaccines as cases surge
item.description: Prime Minister KP Sharma Oli makes a direct plea to Nepal's "oldest friend" as cases numbers rise.

item.title: UK approves Pfizer jab for 12 to 15-year-olds
item.description: The UK regulator says the vaccine is safe and effective and the benefits outweigh risks in this age group.

item.title: Elections watchdog admits errors in reporting Tory donations
item.description: The Electoral Commission says it wrongly disclosed the party received money from a defunct firm.

item.title: Drug dealers caught after undertaking police on M6 hard shoulder
item.description: Cocaine with a street value of £500,000 was found in a car which sped past on a hard shoulder.

item.title: Covid: Pupils fell behind again in second lockdown
item.description: Primary pupils in England fell months behind in maths and reading losing progress made in the autumn.

item.title: Nigeria to suspend Twitter 'indefinitely'
item.description: The suspension comes after the social media giant removed a tweet by President Muhammadu Buhari.

item.title: 'Unseaworthy' Noah's Ark replica detained at Ipswich Waterfront
item.description: The 70m-long (230ft) floating museum features sculptures depicting stories from the Bible.

item.title: 'It's not all about holidays, I miss my family abroad'
item.description: As foreign travel restrictions tighten in the UK, and families are being kept apart because of it.

item.title: Måneskin: The Eurovision winners storming the UK charts
item.description: Italian rock band Måneskin chat about chart domination and finding a fan in Miley Cyrus.

item.title: Lighting a candle for Tiananmen and Hong Kong freedoms
item.description: A Hong Kong tradition mourning the victims of the 1989 crackdown in Beijing is under threat.

item.title: Blackpool's deckchairs set for promenade comeback
item.description: The council has earmarked a new pitch for the chairs on the promenade near Central Pier.

item.title: Why UFO existence is still up in the air...
item.description: A US military report finds mysterious objects seen by Navy pilots remain unexplained, officials say.

item.title: The Afghan policewoman facing abuse at work
item.description: Momena waived her anonymity to talk to the BBC about allegations of abuse in the Afghan Police Force.

item.title: 'We survived, we're resilient and we're back'
item.description: This is how five centenarians celebrated the reopening of Washington DC nursing homes.

item.title: Wolf Alice: Critics laud band's 'third and best' album
item.description: The follow-up to the London indie band's Mercury Prize-winning LP has been called a "masterpiece".

item.title: US troops accidentally raid sunflower oil factory
item.description: They were taking part in a Nato military exercise in Bulgaria but ended up storming the wrong place.

item.title: Valentina Petrillo: 'Better to be a slow happy woman than a fast unhappy man'
item.description: If Valentina Petrillo is selected for Italy's squad in Tokyo this year, she will be the first trans woman Paralympian.

item.title: Parkinson's, AI and me
item.description: The BBC's tech correspondent looks at how AI could change the treatment of Parkinson's disease.

item.title: F1's Max Verstappen: 'I have to believe I'm the best'
item.description: The 23-year-old Dutchman leads Lewis Hamilton in one of the the closest F1 title fights in years.

item.title: Netflix's Sweet Tooth: 6 things to know about the show
item.description: The new show is adapted from a comic book series and has been co-produced by Robert Downey Jr.

item.title: How to protect birds and bats from wind turbines
item.description: As wind farm numbers explode researchers are coming up with more ways to keep wildlife safe.

item.title: Oshin: The gritty Japanese drama that gripped the world
item.description: The 1980s TV show Oshin was a rare Asian global blockbuster that had a lasting cultural impact.

item.title: NFL: How race-based formulas are interfering with concussion lawsuits
item.description: The league faces scrutiny over potentially depriving former black players of injury-related payouts.

item.title: Spurs halt talks with ex-Chelsea boss Conte
item.description: Tottenham call off talks with Antonio Conte about becoming their next manager.

item.title: Williams into French Open fourth round as draw opens up
item.description: Serena Williams remains the highest seed in her half of the French Open draw after overcoming Danielle Collins in the third round.

item.title: Six Man City players in PFA Premier League Team of the Year
item.description: Manchester United's Luke Shaw and Tottenham's Son Heung-min are in the 2020-21 PFA Team of the Year, which is dominated by Manchester City players.

item.title: Laporte makes Spain bow in friendly draw with Portugal
item.description: Manchester City defender Aymeric Laporte makes his Spain debut as they draw with Portugal in a Euro 2020 warm-up in front of 14,743 fans.

item.title: Farah bids to clinch 10,000m Tokyo Olympics spot
item.description: Mo Farah will attempt to secure his place in the 10,000m at this summer's rearranged Tokyo Olympics on Saturday.

item.title: Singapore Grand Prix cancelled as Formula 1 bosses assess replacement options
item.description: The Singapore Grand Prix is called off this year and Formula 1 is assessing its options to replace the race, BBC Sport can reveal.

item.title: Italy rout Czech Republic for eighth consecutive win without conceding
item.description: Italy brush aside the Czech Republic in their final Euro 2020 warm-up game for an eighth win in a row without conceding.

item.title: What are the rules for travelling to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: Foreign holidays are now possible, but travellers must follow strict rules on their return.

item.title: 'Nepal variant': What's the mutation stopping green list trips to Portugal?
item.description: Ministers have raised concerns over a mutation to the Delta variant first identified in India.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Covid-19 rules in Wales are changing - but for many in Scotland the lifting of lockdown has been "paused".

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 38 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid: What do under-30s need to know about the vaccine?
item.description: The vaccine rollout is now reaching younger adults. What do they need to know about getting jabbed?

item.title: Covid-19: Could a third wave change 21 June plans in England?
item.description: Rising coronavirus cases have called the planned 21 June relaxing of rules in England into question.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Do social distance rules apply after both vaccine jabs?
item.description: Guidance on hugging close friends and family has being relaxed in England and Scotland.

item.title: Travel guide to Spain, Portugal, France and more holiday hotspots
item.description: What you need to know about travelling abroad to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: Coronavirus: When can we stop wearing face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Rules are relaxing, but masks are still needed in some settings - here's where and why.

item.title: Tokyo Olympic Games: When are they and will they go ahead despite Covid?
item.description: The Tokyo Summer Olympics are due to start in July, despite a surge in Covid cases in Japan.

item.title: Covid: How is Europe lifting lockdown restrictions?
item.description: A third Covid wave hit much of Europe hard but now gradually lockdowns are being eased.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about returning to work?

item.title: Covid vaccine update: Those that work - and the others on the way
item.description: Covid vaccination campaigns are under way in the UK and across the world.

item.title: Lockdown muscle loss: Five ways to get back in shape
item.description: Lockdown inactivity may have left people with weaker muscles - there are simple solutions.

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the risk of Covid on public transport?
item.description: As UK coronavirus restrictions are relaxed, public transport could become much busier.

item.title: How are eviction rules for renters and landlords changing?
item.description: The eviction ban is ending, but what does that mean?

item.title: The Motherload: How pandemic anger almost destroyed a mums' support group
item.description: Abusive messages from angry mums during lockdown almost caused the founder of The Motherload to close it down.

item.title: The children selling explicit videos on OnlyFans
item.description: British subscription site OnlyFans is failing to prevent underage users from selling and appearing in explicit videos, a BBC investigation has found.

item.title: How Ben Crump became America's go-to police brutality lawyer
item.description: When families lose a loved one in a police shooting, more often than not Ben Crump gets a call. Why is he the go-to man?

item.title: Samantha Azzopardi: Australia's notorious con artist sentenced for child theft
item.description: Authorities are baffled by the "bizarre crime" of a serial con artist who has travelled the world.

item.title: After a 32-year battle for justice, what is Hillsborough's legacy?
item.description: As the collapse of the last criminal trial marks the end of a long legal road, Judith Moritz asks what the legacy of Britain’s worst sports disaster is.
